captions.text: [ENGINE SOUNDS]

There are several reasons why
I love the new Cayman.
This is one of them.
[TIRES SCREECHING]

It is one of the supreme, modern
driving experiences.

OK, short of being silly and
doing big skids the whole

time, what is it about this car
that I find so beguiling?

Well, as a complete package as
a compact sports car, I find

myself wondering what more
it could give me.

It's not perfect, and we'll
come to the reasons why it

might not quite reach
perfection later on.

But if you were to go and
spend between 40,000 and

50,000 pounds on a small sports
car, I just don't know
what more you could want.

And, of course, it now
looks brilliant.

So you get the driving
experience and a car you could
be proud to look at as well.

If I was another car
manufacturer trying to enter

this space now, I'd be
very worried indeed.
[TIRES SCREECHING]

The essence of the Cayman, for
me, is the way that it will
turn into a corner.

I just haven't driven a car
that's so instinctive before.
Well, I have.
It was the previous Cayman.

You can drive this car neatly
and really enjoy the process.
You turn the wheel.

It loads up a bit, and
the car's just agile.
It wants to change direction.
Electric powered steering--

yes, it's lacking some steering
feel over the
previous car.
That's not a good thing.

But we're stuck with
these electric
systems now, I suppose.

And this one, once you get
beyond that lack of feel, it's
so instinctive.

You can just put the car within
inches of where you
want to be.

It's a car that just wants to
be driven down twisty roads.
It wants to be switchbacking.

It wants to just change
direction the whole time.
It's got an appetite for it.

It is enthralling
and addictive.
[ENGINE SOUNDS]

Now, there are probably two
fundamental questions about
the new Cayman.

And, interestingly, none of them
requires an answer about

a rival car at the moment,
because I don't think it
really has a rival.

Exide V6 is just too hard
core, it's not as
every day as this.

So the questions are, should you
upgrade your two-year-old

Cayman S and spend an extra
25,000, 30,000 pounds to buy
this new car?
I would if it was mine.

And should you just have a
Boxster, because the Boxster

should offer the same
experience,
really, or 99% of it.

And the roof can go down
when you want it to.

That's a tricky one, that
second one for me.

I just love the way
this car looks.

I always want the hard top
driving experience, as well,
or most of the time.

So I probably would
have this car.

It also drives in a more
precise manner.

I know the Boxster is great, but
there's just an extra edge
of brilliance about this car.

The Cayman S uses effectively
the same 3.4 liter flat six as

the Boxter S, but an ECU
fiddle gives another 10
horsepower.

So that's 325 horsepower and
273 foot pounds of torque.

It weighs 1,350 kilograms and
Porsche claims that this PDK

and Sport Chrono Plus version
will hit 62 miles an hour in

4.7 seconds and do 176 miles
an hour flat out.

That's fast enough for
most of us, isn't it?

This car was fitted
with optional
carbon ceramic brakes.

Porsche really has the pedal
feel nailed with them these

days, but at five grand, they're
just so expensive.

There's a touch more
boot space.

The new sat nav screen is
standard Porsche fair.
And you know what?

It's a beautifully
finished cabin.

The driving position is bang on,
but it somehow isn't quite

funky enough for that
new exterior.

Overall though, it feels
like a quality
item with real presence.

The Cayman is not intended to
be a track car, but the only

place you can really explore
what this chassis is all about
is the track.

So we're here at Portimao, one
of the great circuits in
Europe in Portugal.

And we've got a couple
of laps.

So let's see what
it's all about.

We're not trying to go
as fast as possible.

We're trying to explore how
the Cayman behaves.

I'm in Sport Plus, so I've got
the fastest gear shifts.

I've got my sports exhaust on,
and let's see what happens.
Fast gear shifts.

Again, you've got that lovely
turning on the car.

Anyone that races will tell you
that the front of the car

is absolutely imperative
that it turns where
you want it to go.
[ENGINE SOUNDS]
Listen to the motor.
Isn't that a great sound?
Revving out now.
Oh, that's about seven six.

Breaking nice and late
into this hairpin.

Really good responsive
break pedal.
This car's got ceramics.
Traction issues--

I'm flat out in second
out of that hairpin.
No worries whatsoever.

The circuit really starts
to flow now.
Quick over this crest.
Let's get up this hill.
Takes it all.

A little bit of understep,
because I was a bit
heavy on that then.

I've got to remember where this
goes over this crest.
Look at this fast turn here.
Fantastic stuff.
The car's got so much balance.

OK, you get it into the corner
nicely, but mid-corner it
gives you options.

Peel off the throttle a
bit and the nose just
comes back into line.

Hoof it and you do feel a
suggestion of oversteer.

That is the essence of a
great mid-engine car.

And it's why the Cayman will
always slightly have an
advantage over the 911.

Now this bloody, epic fast right
hander, which I'm going

to be a little bit
easy through.

Let it run wide, and now quick
down the straight.

Again, it just has
so much balance.

It's so responsive, and you
feel enormous confidence.
Like the engine as well.

See, it doesn't feel
any stronger than
it does in the Boxster.

You don't notice the 10
horsepower like that.

Although, it does seem quite
keen to overcome the rear

tires sometimes, but that's as
it was in the Boxster as well.

One thing you get over the
911, which is quite

interesting, is that because the
motor is that much closer

to you, as are the intakes, you
get more induction noise.

You just get a little bit
more induction noise.
The whole cabin is full of it.
That feels pretty good to me.
[TIRES SCREECHING]

Feels pretty well
balanced to me.

This car brings mixed
emotions.

So much joy for anyone lucky
enough to own one because it
is just a great driver's car.

But also a little sadness for
the poor rival companies who

will now try to beat it, because
theirs is a very, very
tough task.

The Cayman is not only the best
car of its type to drive,

it's now the most
desirable too.

title: 2013 Porsche Cayman S Thrashed - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Anderson C

comments.text:
Honestly, I was never a big Porsche fan, but I rented a standard Boxster 
with manual transmission (mainly because it was the only sporty car to rent 
nearby) for a weekend and I my only complain was indeed the steering feel. 
It was precise and everything but somehow the steering in my good old 323i 
feels more alive. Yes, I would love to buy something more hardcore one day, 
but then I probably wouldn't want to take a car like an Elise on a long 
trip to the alps, where I had to use motorways and drive in bad weather 
conditions. So, as I favour coupés over convertibles, I really can't think 
of anything that would compare to a Cayman on the current market. 
Especially since the looks are just right.﻿

comments.author: david dykeman

comments.text:
This is my dream car, ever since I first saw it I've wanted it.  Plus it is 
within the boundaries of being affordable.  The thing is, the base price is 
certainly very reasonable for a sports car and especially a Porsche, but 
things start to go downhill as soon as you start adding in any extras. 
 Pretty soon you rack up another 10-20k on things like paint, interior, 
seatbelts, PDK, suspension, parking sensors, cruise control etc.  Its also 
the little things that get you, like $200 for having the Porsche symbol on 
the wheels in colour, or $2000 for having the dials in the colour of your 
car.  It's still reasonable, but less affordable.  Then there's the slight 
issue of the fact that in Australia there's pretty much at least a 100% 
surcharge on all luxury cars.  "Oh wow, look at that Cayman S!  Only 60k! 
 Oh, lol, jks, its Australia, more like 120k..."﻿
comments.author: Alexander Young

comments.text: yeh porsche are known for optional extras

comments.author: Moose75528

comments.text:
Recently I was browsing around a Porsche dealership in a dreamstate where I 
saw 5 Caymans in 5 different colours. The 3 that stood out the most to me 
were the Sapphire Blue, Agate Grey and Rhodium Silver, with light Pebble 
Grey interiors.

Out of those 3 it would be between the Sapphire Blue and Rhodium Silver 
which both show the Cayman's lines really well without being too in yer 
face, but they're way too expensive. A new, (almost fully loaded), Cayman 
is £65-£70K ($109-$117K.)

Lovely looking car though, and if I was in the market for a small 2 seater 
sportscar it would be a very tough choice between the Cayman S and the 
Jaguar F Type Coupe, which is as equally gorgeous in the metal.﻿

comments.author: Johan Melander

comments.text:
+swunt10  He brought it up because he has a damn good point.  The RX-7 was 
the mid 90s version of the Cayman, near perfect 50/50 weight distribution, 
2 seat rwd pure sports car, an incredible engine that can easily put out 
300rwhp+ with a few mods (i.e. not going single turbo), weighed about 
2800lbs loaded, and cornered like nothing else.  The FD is a legend.  I 
promise you, it may say "mazda" on the rear but it will give the 981s a run 
for it's money (again, provided it's lightly modded.  If stock, compare it 
to the base Cayman - very similar performance).

Single turbo FD with coilovers, etc?  Or an LSx swap FD?  RX-7 stomps the 
Cayman S in either case, and I love Porsche.  Truth is truth however.﻿
comments.author: pursuinginsanity

comments.text: I want this car so bad. This video doesn't help my lust.﻿

comments.text:
I'd like to see porsche make a mid engine sports car that competes or tops 
the performance of the 911 in the next 10-20 years. They can do it, 
everyone knows it. However, to do so would cease the 911s' existence and I 
don't know if that day will ever come. Don't get me wrong the 911 has 
always been a favorite of mine, but if porsche achieved cayman results but 
with a more powerful vehicle, why that would be something unique. I'd like 
to here from others on there thoughts of Porsche far from now future. ﻿
comments.author: GoProBro

comments.text:
No it won't because it will be a 4 cylinder 911 beater, which will never be 
as good as a 6 in my view. So the 911 will continue to exist and evolve 
(hopefully)

comments.text:
If we are to believe Walter Röhrl, who did the setup of many Porsche's 
including the Boxster and 911, then the GT3 is so good that he cannot tell 
whether he is a good driver or not anymore! And the rear wheel steering 
totally neuralizes the fact that the 911 is rear engine, he says.

The turbo already has the rear steering and nothing prevents Porsche from 
introducing it for other 911s with the next generation. Same goes for GT3 
steering and PDK setup... Porsche can make a Boxster that is as good as the 
911 - but they can always make a better 911, as well ;)
comments.author: Baerchenization

comments.text:
Something unique? The 911 is unique among its company. A mid-engine 911 
level Porsche would just be another of the bunch already available.

No shit: My uncle is actually getting me a '14 Cayman as a gift (and my 
first car), so I'm pretty much gonna have to expect people to talk shit 
about me being "spoiled" or "pathetic" simply for eventually owning a 
Porsche.  People need to realize it's still a reliable and reasonably 
priced (and exhilarating) sports car.  You're getting more than what you 
pay for with the Cayman, if you think about it.﻿

comments.author: n0hav0cyet

comments.text:
+n0hav0cyet
I got my first car as a gift as well. It was a 10 years old Bmw 320 and I 
felt 'guilty' for owning such a big car. We bought it for more or less 
2500€ but it was before Euro. Last summer I bought myself a Porsche.

I know American and European cultures are really different but I would be 
shame to give a brand new Porsche as a gift to a young guy. I would assume 
your family background is quite upperclass but still I find it 
inappropriate.
comments.author: ca co

comments.text:
+n0hav0cyet dude I know, you just got it right! I really believe that the 
guys at Porsche are proud and glad that you're an owner of their fine 
machines. We live in a tough world, a world of envy and misunderstandings, 
the only thing that make's me sad is your uncle. I hope he makes it. Have a 
hug from me, and please enjoy!!

comments.author: n0hav0cyet

comments.text:
Of course you need to be a professional driver to know how to handle a car 
like that.  I'm not one to be stupid enough to drift across a traffic lane 
on my first try, so that's good.  I thank thou for the compliments and 
suggestion and I'll take the track into consideration.

I honestly have been practicing myself with my driving in a shitty '97 Ford 
Escort, but I'm no longer driving it due to its jumbled up transmission and 
that it's apparently not worth fixing anymore.  Eh.  Things come and go.
comments.author: n0hav0cyet

comments.text:
+n0hav0cyet That's a very powerful car to own as a first car, plus 
mid-engine  - please take care!  If I were you I'd take it down to the 
nearest track & skid pan and really get a feel for how it behaves when it 
lets go.  Sorry for lecturing, but I know too many young guys who have 
killed themselves in powerful cars they were not experienced enough to 
control properly - Chris makes it look easy - it's not.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text: +Setman Aye, verily.  Keeping all of that in mind, dude.  Thanks.
comments.author: n0hav0cyet

comments.text:
terrible about your uncle and the nit wits harassing you about everything 
(especially the person claiming to be speaking for Christians… very 
insensitive whether or not they were being serious or simply mocking). 
 however, you even said yourself that you expected negative feedback when 
you first posted so don't be shocked that you're getting busted on … be 
thankful for your gift, but also careful how you present the info if you 
don't want a backlash (e.g... leave out details like it was a gift, or that 
it's your first car.. you're just opening yourself up, mate.)  anyway enjoy 
the car and sorry for your loss.

comments.author: DubaiWatchGuy

comments.text:
+IRL2DXB "spark an idea in myself". If that is a person and/or an object 
and/or a passionate-and-obsessional habit and/or ideas and ideals.

If that is the right twin flame or soulmate for you...

If that is a car with physic combinations of: cutest looking (VW Beetles) 
and/or sexiest looking (Porsches) and/or coolest looking (varies) and/or 
most luxuries (Mercedes Benz) and/or a combination of 
cool-cute-luxuries-sexy looking (2014 Audi TT models only, not the 2015 
models) and/or still plain looking (VW Golfs and VW Polos are plain looking 
in my opinion).

Next, is the drivetrain combination of the car: FF (current VW Beetles) or 
FR (2014 Mazda Miata) or FMR (Chevrolet Corvettes) or F4 (Audi, Subaru, 
etc) or FM4 (Ferrari FF) or MR (Porsche Cayman GTS) or M4 (Porsche 918 
Spyder) or RR (Porsche 911 GT3) or R4 (Porsche 911 Turbo S).

Next, is the engine type combination of the car: Single Turbo or Twin Turbo 
or Naturally Aspirated or Supercharger.

(If you want to know both the drivetrain and engine type of the 
if-not-fastest cars in the world: Formula 1, they are Midrear-engined 
Rear-wheel drive (MR) and they are Naturally Aspirated (NA), according to 
Wikipedia... Or is it Red Bull racing cars?) (The fastest racing rally cars 
are Front-engined 4WD (F4)...)

If neither inspires you, then it must be a habit then of some sort. Ohhh, I 
can think of one: the porn industry, but that is NOT healthy for any human 
beings and must be avoided.

Maybe it's the internet such as interest searching and get paid while doing 
it... Something you already know how to do such as cooking, doing chores, 
doing basic things and try to generate money out of those habits with the 
littlest of things...

Maybe it's something easy or hard to do...

Maybe it's an idea! I got two unique ideas that I really don't care if I 
get money out of it or not, just someone please do this for me: 4WD 
Volkswagen Beetles, and a new Warcraft III (<-- a computer game) Tavern 
Hero that let's people retire way faster out of the game. I just know these 
will make a huge impact in the world on Earth! I just don't take action for 
it, but you can if you wanna...

I can go on and on...

Visit rich people's houses and apartments and learn what they do. Find out 
where they live. And then ask them their "secrets" to financial success. 
Scout around out there. Be social. Have new friends that has what you don't 
have at the moment (in this case: rich friends, and eventually you'll 
become one of them!).

If that does not work, go to very expensive car dealerships and something 
similar that sell above the $100,000 range and up and ask for their 
business cards and whatever else. Chat with as many of these people as you 
can, and don't give up if one person wants to lay you off. If you truly 
want to be financially be rich, then don't lie to yourself and be 
discouraged by someone who will try to trip you and discourage you - move 
on to someone else who will really help you get what you desire.

(Obviously, if you ask a poor person how to be rich, almost all they do is 
complain about how "life is hard for me" and "this bad happening and that" 
and they obviously don't know what they are talking about when it comes to 
generating huge profits, so avoid these people...)

Use every option that you have at the moment and abuse those options 
nicely: your feet: go to rich locations and businesses.

Your mind: you think what you want and how you feel about it. Be sure 
whatever you hear with your ears will go into your permanent memory and 
abuse it as if tying your own shoe laces without thinking about it, 
becoming a habit. Your own mind can become like an automatic money 
generating machine: not thinking while doing it, and just do it without 
distraction. Just don't get greedy.

Your mouth: make sure you are serious, and don't let fear and discourage 
stand in your way of speaking out your mind to those that have what you 
want. And don't waste time talking nonsense, as that will not profit you 
unless you want to relax and get back on track in your life.

Your ears: you got these, so listen up and listen carefully. if you truly 
care about what is being out spoken, don't let it go in of one ear out to 
the other.

Your nose: I suppose if you would want to have a food business that will 
help people lose weight and cure their diseases and illness without 
negative side effects - something helpful that can be outlawed by 
governments, as real cures wouldn't be profitable if every single human 
being is healthy, but right now too many people are sick in the US, so 
profiting from food-medicine sell ups is possible for decades long at this 
rate... And there is such a thing from naturalcures.com called "The 
No-Hunger Bread". Find out the ingredients and you give it a try. If it 
works, you secretly get this bread into YOUR business secretly and under 
disguise if possible. Smell this delicious bread, and smell it's potential 
victory!

I'm sure you can ask money from the government to start a small business 
and sell whatever stuff that YOU personally like to use. What is it that 
you need daily? - you sell those. What is it you like to eat daily? - you 
sell those.
You do not have to start selling inside in a building: go to a market where 
you sell stuff outside and outdoors. Buy a stand and a table to sell your 
stuff. And if your desperate, sell them at your home. But maybe you need a 
lawful license or something or a selling permit to start selling some 
really useful food. I've seen people in carts selling stuff and while they 
travel inside subway stations and on board trains... So...

There's a fish can that is the best fish can I ever eaten in my life so far 
called: Rugen Fisch - Smoked Herring Fillets - with vegetable oil and own 
juice (rugenfisch.de).

Eating these with delicious bread and with a fork and they are ready to be 
eaten. Some long looking greenish onions are also good while eating these 
fish can...

And don't invest in things that you don't like using, because if you don't 
like it - it's mostly likely others don't like it either. If you know 
that's overall good, it will sell and probably run out of stock, too. Then 
you scale it from 1 to 10 (1 is very bad to 10 excellent). Sell the as many 
9's and 10's as you can, and avoid the 4s and belowers...

I could go on and on, but I will end it here for now... I overall was happy 
that I typed these in... You think for yourself now, guys... And rely on 
God Jesus Christ to make your prayers come true... Amen.

+Victor K
"But i don't care about balance. If a car sounds better and looks better 
and feels better, i want it more."

"I have driven manual cars before. And no i would never take my car to the 
track. Why would I? I can't find joy in destroying my car like that. I take 
care of my cars."

Hmmm... with lines like that, it's no surprise that you have no 
appreciation for the Cayman. Also, the car that is better balanced, is also 
going to feel better to drive. When Chris Harris and MANY other reviewers 
agree that this is one of "the supreme modern driving experiences" they're 
not talking about posing in a car. They're judging it as a driver's car. To 
me, you don't count as a driver. 

You don't have to "destroy" your car to drive it hard and enjoy it. These 
cars are meant to be driven...at least Porsches are. Maybe Jags don't have 
the same reputation of being able to be driven hard.

servicing costs. Fuel costs. Real world stuff, not this fishtailing about, 
license losing, street chav driving. There, I said it!

cars over any of theirs any day a week.
